Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support from polls to back up the statement that John Cornyn always loses to any conservative the voters have heard about.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that being labeled as a liberal makes John Cornyn vulnerable from the right, but it is questionable whether Cornyn can be accurately described as liberal.
Exist alternative explanation: There are alternative explanations for the polling results, such as Cornyn's favorability ratings dropping among Texas conservatives, which could have fueled talk of a primary challenge.
Understate: The claim may understate the support that John Cornyn has in hypothetical one-on-one faceoffs with certain party figures, as indicated by a poll that showed him ahead in those matchups.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a comprehensive analysis of all the available polling data and only focusing on specific instances that support the claim.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the vulnerability of John Cornyn from the right by stating that he always loses to any conservative the voters have heard about, without considering the specific context and circumstances of each election.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that in some polls, such as the University of Texas and Texas Tribune poll, Cornyn was leading against little-known opponents.
